job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: - I worked with some great people. Unfortunately, this is greatly overshadowed by many who I worked with, specifically those making decisions, who weren’t great. Typically, anyone in a student-facing role who has anything positive to say is either new and doesn’t know any better or has been there forever and is unwilling to challenge any decisions.
cons:
- Low starting pay and practically non-existent raises despite increasing workload and additional responsibilities. In the 3.5 years I worked there, I received a single raise of about 1%. 
- Those who make decisions don’t seek or listen to feedback from those who are affected by the decisions and doing the work.
- Extreme lack of set policies and procedures. I worked in a student-facing role and the lack of standardization was unbelievable. This extended to training practices. 
- High turnover in certain departments that created challenges with productivity in other departments. 
- I could honestly go on and on. Keep in mind that the overall Glassdoor score is inflated by part-time student workers.

review_title: What I wish I had known before starting
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Depending on your department, there are some great professors to work with that will try to be flexible with you and mentor you.
cons:
1. The pay is extremely unstable and the contracts change every semester.
2. There is minimal support from the university for your research.
3. You are limited to 28 hours per week (20 for an international student) on paper, but will work more hours than this.
4. Unless you are being paid from a research grant, you will need to do 20 hours of TA work on top of your research work.
5. You have to be enrolled in order to take this position and there is currently no tuition reimbursement, discount, or scholarship that comes with the position effectively lowering your base pay.

job_title: Graphic Designer in Kansas City, MO
pros: Your colleagues are top notch. Care about you and your family. The direct report, although doesn't have much control in the office, listens and empathizes with your concerns. Great work/life balance, rarely work late, ok benefits, creative expectation is low.
cons: Creative expectation is low. Generally speaking, Clients do not fully respect our office and our role. Majority of leadership has minimal to 0 history in the creative process let alone managing creatives. Creative expectations are low and as a result the work completed fails to meet the high standard any creative (in house or not) should have set. Most of the leadership heavily micro manage the Designers and Editors.

job_title: Director in Kansas City, MO
pros: The students are amazing and inspiring. There are still some great staff and faculty members there, though people have been leaving in droves. UMKC offers generous amounts of vacation leave, sick time, personal days, and holidays. Benefits were historically very good, but have been getting cut. It's a small, pretty campus in a great area of the city.
cons: The politics of higher level administration have ruined UMKC. I was there over a decade; it used to be a wonderful place to work, but by the time I left a year ago, employee morale had hit rock bottom. The entire campus was a hostile work environment. It's my understanding things have only gotten worse. I hear of 2-3 people per week who leave - and they are not replaced. In hindsight, I feel like I worked in an "abusive environment." We certainly were not appreciated. Really sad. The students deserve better.

job_title: Student Support Specialist in Kansas City, MO
pros:
-Job autonomy
-75% tuition discount for employee, 50% discount for spouse (can be same sex) and dependents
-Supportive health initiatives
-Salaried workers accrue 17-22 vacation days per year
-Student interaction rewarding
cons:
-Work load not equitable; some staff work well over 40 hours while others, often in leadership roles, work well under 40
-Administration just beneath Chancellor is embarrassingly dysfunctional
-Very little to no salary increases; start low, stay low-this causing low morale
-MU system recently reviewed all job titles/pay, hadn't since 1970's, most inequities not corrected

review_title: great people, low pay, high cost for parking for employees, very little to no raises
job_title: in Kansas City, MO
pros:
*great co-workers, great manager - no micromanaging
*beautiful campus
*flexible in working with employees who wish to attend classes, 75% off tuition for employees
*it is so much better working in higher education than other sectors that only care about the bottom line
*opportunities for health classes and educational seminars through wellness program
*decent benefits, 1 week vacation, 12 sick days, 4 personal days, paid holidays, health insurance.
cons:
*low pay, no negotiation
*very little employee recognition
*employees must pay to park
*only one raise in many years of service, raises are not based off of review but are university wide 1% raises *
*the cost for health insurance is taken out twice on your first check - be warned
*computer system has a lot of issues which are never fixed, this gets frustrating after a few years
*difficult to get promoted from within

review_title: Low salary, low career growth, flexible schedule
job_title: Assistant Teaching PRofessor in Kansas City, MO
pros:
- Flexible schedule.
- Work-life balance.
- Rather relaxed environment.
- Friendly colleagues.
- Some appreciative students.
cons:
- Very low salary for someone with a PhD degree, and a lot of experience ($61K).
- No hope for any career advancement at all. Once you are an NTT teaching professor, to them, you will always be that. The most you can be is an associate teaching professor, which financially, means absolutely nothing.
- Even with a PhD degree and a lot of awards, experience, some funding, training, etc, they wouldn't consider you for a tenure-track position, not in your dreams.
- People around you, while very respectful, don't see any potential in you. They only think of you as a teaching professor, with no research skills.

job_title: Executive Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Very relaxed environment, people are very friendly and welcoming. Supervisor is willing to go above and beyond to make my schedule flexible with my class schedule so I can graduate on time. The pay is pretty good too, especially with it being part time. Low stress level typically.
cons: Training was a bit lacking... I was on day two without anyone helping me and basically got a "good luck" from my trainer. My supervisor was out sick, so I am not sure if that would have happened if she was here, as she has a strong attention to detail. I definitely feel like I am just expected to "know" everything off the top of my head, after only being here six months with little to no training.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: The location is centrally located and close to everything in the city.  It's an easy commute and the area is safe overall.  The laid back university environment allows for a high level of autonomy.  You're able to tweak and make adjustments so you remain effective.
cons: There are few opportunities to advance which can become demoralizing.  There are also department politics in play which slows down productivity.  The pay has gotten better, but its still below the city's average for your title.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Kansas City, MO
pros: Broad range of students - some brilliant, others not well prepared academically.  Students are pleasant - not the entitlement mentality you sometimes see at top-tier schools.  Nice collaboration across different parts of the campus.  Becoming more prominent because of location in Kansas City.  Nice library renovation, new business school building.  Compensation and benefits are competitive.
cons: This school is underfunded - they've had some success attracting wealthy donors, but they need much more.  The lesser-prepared  undergrad students hold back the others, and also contribute to a less-than ideal graduation rate.  The school should think about being more selective and/or providing more remedial and supportive students to students.

review_title: A great place to learn to teach
job_title: Student Teacher in Kansas City, MO
pros: Although I was a lowly grad student, UMKC gave me full autonomy over the courses I taught. I was able to design the course, write the syllabus, choose all the readings, set the attendance policy, etc.--really everything that full professors do. In the meantime, there was no administrative interference, yet plenty of help when I needed it. A great experience over all. I learned a lot about teaching.
cons: I had to share an office with three other student teachers, which might be common practice, but I still felt apologetic when students would come in and find like four teachers in there--who were often visiting students of their own.

job_title: Lecturer in Kansas City, MO
pros: Good benefits. Vacation time during school breaks, typical of most university/college jobs
cons: The higher education field in MO is no longer stable. The University of Missouri system is going through dramatic budget cuts. I taught there full time for 12 years, and my contract was not renewed, yet multiple adjuncts kept their positions with an increase in course load, and more adjuncts were hired. I was cheated and left bitter. They did me dirty.

job_title: Academic Advisor in Kansas City, MO
pros: Good benefits. Students! Parking was convenient.
cons: Lots of silos. Not a lot of respect for your knowledge or prior experience. Locked in old ways of doing things. At least in my department, no one was student centered. It was all about how things would effect them. Was let go with no explanation and still waiting to get paid, which is against Missouri law.

review_title: Difficult to Move Up--or Laterally--as a Staff Member
job_title: Administrative Associate in Kansas City, MO
pros:
-Great benefits, including generous amount of time off during the Christmas season
-75% discount on tuition
-50% discount on spouse/children's tuition after 5 years' employment
-Many opportunities to get involved with campus activities
cons:
-Definite faculty/staff split in terms of collegiality
-Many changes in the last several years have left many feeling out of the loop
-Next to impossible to get rid of poor employees in any position
-Very difficult to get promoted within your position (say if you take on  new job duties) or to move to another department/school
-Everything moves very, very slowly--frustrating when you want to accomplish something now

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Berlin
pros: It was a decent place to work a few years ago.
cons: Budget issues have created a very terrible work environment. Employees are on edge and are terrified of getting laid off. There is a hiring freeze in place. Managers are not being very open about what's going on behind the scenes and several people have left the university already.  A recent climate survey showed employees feel under paid and that there is little to no opportunity for advancement.

job_title: Office Support Assistant II in Berlin
pros: I'm developmentally disabled, and I've been accommodated in so many ways, ranging from a maxiflex schedule to being able to work from home.  Everyone I work with is friendly, my boss is great, and it's a university I can be proud to work for.
cons: Budget cuts keep happening, so don't expect much in the way of wage growth.

job_title: Student Services Coordinator and Adjunct Faculty in Berlin
pros: It is a dynamic place to work. I enjoy the smaller campus feel and interactions with students. The campus is set in urban Kansas City, but it has great resources and support for faculty and staff.
cons: Somethings in Higher Education never work as fast or as smoothly as is wanted. UMKC is no exception to that rule. Though UMKC can be bogged down by needless policies and procedures.

job_title: Student Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros:
The working time is very flexible. As a student I easily balance my work and academic study.
Staffs are very friendly,  You can ask anyone if you have any problems. They are very happy to help you.
cons:
The salary is not very attractive comparing to other job.
This is a very small office and it is not a big platform for your career development.
Jobs are related to administration.

job_title: Coordinator in Kansas City, MO
pros:
Great coworkers
Fun atmosphere
Not micromanaged by boss
Benefit of reduction in tuition for you and family memebers
cons:
This office is SEVERELY understaffed (7 employees below federal standards) so there is so much work pushed on each advisor. 
The software being used in that office is terrible, and should be updated by the university.

job_title: Event Staff in Kansas City, MO
pros: Flexible hours, friendly employees, and a professional work atmosphere that lead me to have a good experience. I have no real complaints.
cons: The position was minimum wage which is no one's ideal pay, but it was an overall fun job to work at. It was fast paced and kept you moving.

job_title: Assistant Teaching PRofessor in Kansas City, MO
pros: Chair was a great supervisor, very supportive, helpful, and the faculty were very enjoyable to be around
cons: dental school is a horrible place to teach. Dental Hygiene program coddles the students and many are downright dishonest and unethical. There is a "whose prof sucks worse" culture among the students. They have gone through something like 5 faculty in 6 years to teach the same course in this program.

job_title: Student Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: The position provides a lot flexibility in your work schedule, which is great for scholars who need to frequently travel out of town. The environment is low stress and the tasks are easy to perform.
cons: Overall, the University itself is very disorganized in terms of interdepartmental communication. The Library itself is competent, but watch out if you ever have to resolve anything over in administration.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great working place, flexible hours, great bosses. It's definitely a nice on campus job for any student. The work performed takes usually 70% of any shift, but the 30% remaining can be used for homeworks
cons: Limited mobility, no raises and definitely a lot of mad teachers. People are usually not careful with the equipment so cleaning, maintenance etc has to be done continiously.

review_title: Some great people, but a messed up place!
job_title: Director II (Student Affairs) in Kansas City, MO
pros: There are some wonderful, dedicated people who work there, and the students are fabulous. It's a nice sized campus in a lovely part of the city. Very liberal, especially for the Midwest!
cons: The politics are a nightmare! Senior leadership leaves a lot to be desired. Staff are worked to death for little pay and raises are paltry or non-existant. Lack of support for staff in management roles.

review_title: Okay job, provided you're okay with low pay
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros:
-Teach in academic environment
-Flexibility in setting office hours, lesson plans, grading procedures
-Employees generally happy
cons:
-Favoritism abounds, interoffice politics everywhere
-Low pay compared to other universities, every grad student must have two jobs
-No chance of advancement, academic departments do not hire former UMKC students

job_title: Supplemental Instructor in Kansas City, MO
pros:
Opportunity to work intimately with faculty

Develop communication and teaching skills

Workload was not too demanding—all prep work completed in short order.
cons:
The pay was not very satisfactory.

I wish I had more creative freedom in my position, but it was very rigid.

review_title: Work Study - School of Computing & Engineering
job_title: Work-Study Student in Kansas City, MO
pros:
Pays better than most work-study departments on campus.
Dean's office staff is friendly and open to questions and discussions.
Easy to request time off for class-related issues.
cons: Someone doesn't understand how to turn the coffee pot off after it's empty - routinely cleaned burned coffee.

review_title: This was a Midwestern-friendly yet rigorous environment to work.
job_title: Instructor in Kansas City, MO
pros: International professors and student body; smaller university, but connected to 4 other university of Missouri schools; Kansas City has a nice mix of urban lifestyle, yet can be rural if you live further away.
cons: Pay may be moderate, but cost of living is much less; campus is spread out in the city with insufficient parking; no good commuter options; some crime throughout the area.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: I've got an excellent environment here to build up my research career on Biomechanics. I've got an excellent supervisor, some other nice people to work with.
cons: As an international graduate research/teaching assistant, I have some issues with their health insurance system, percentage  of tuition waiver and pay scale for  GTA/GRA which can made life very difficult.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Kansas City, MO
pros: A lot of autonomy and creative possibilities. Administrative assistants very helpful. Meaningful work. Love the students. Good benefits.
cons: Shrinking funding by state legislature. Dollar driven administrators who just suck up money while adding extra work on those who actually teach and serve students. Little recognition for hard work or meaningful support from overpaid deans and vice chancellors. Very top-heavy.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: flexible schedule but work load  varies from student to student due to research that is being done; great resources throughout department
cons: working on the weekends sometimes is the best time to get experiments done without disruption; usually work on holidays

job_title: Academic Advisor in Kansas City, MO
pros: Co-Workers great; enjoyed a people- centered job; got to meet the public; safe and stimulating work environment; nice boss to work for
cons: Boardroom meeting too often with too little actual results; always felt time could have been more productively spent; more flexible work schedule would have been nice

job_title: Tutor in Kansas City, MO
pros: If you go to school there, it's good to work on campus. If you graduated from there it's probably pretty easy to find a job of some kind.
cons: The building I worked in was old and should be torn down. Resources are not allocated to put emphasis on science. IT is pretty terrible.

job_title: Lab Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Allow to study while working. This job is easy, not many people ask about computer problems. It's a great job for students who want to focus on studying
cons: It is a little bit boring because you mainly sit there without doing anything. It's minimum wage

review_title: Umkc got me in front of the right people.
job_title: One Card Office in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great networking events, wonderful staff, great experiences, a very diverse student body allows you to really meet individuals from all walks of life.
cons: Hard to get recognition for achievements, career advancement is not talked about extensively, you have to take the initiative to utilize services that you pay for.

review_title: The business school is very good. Challenging courses and helpful staff.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros:
Knowledgeable staff. 
Good infrastructure.
Very entrepreneurship oriented.
Encourage entrepreneurship.
School is well known in the KC area. 
Good campus recruiting for accounting/finance majors.
cons: The school though well known in the KC area is still relatively unknown outside of it. Campus recruiting for masters students in fields other than Accounting and Finance isn't good.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great pay, great benefits, most of the people are great here
cons: The setup of the department makes zero sense. Tedious processes put in place by people that have never worked anywhere else. Zero value is added. Leadership is the definition of the Peter principle. People promoted based on seniority, not qualification. No one in the marketing department has a marketing background. Journalism experience doesn't equate to Project Management experience. I sincerely regret ever taking this job and feel I was seriously mislead during the interview process.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Tuition discount for employees, easy to get time off most of the time
cons: Little to no raises, and low raises when given.   Last raise given almost two years ago was only 2%.  Parking is crazy expensive!  Little advancement.  Many positions require masters degrees but do not pay  at a masters level.

job_title: PhD Student/Graduate Research Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Positive climate, research intensive. People are very friendly and encouraging. Goal oriented atmosphere with high level of competition. Upper management is strong and effective.
cons: underpaid employees, Bad infrastructure. Older instrumentation and IT support. Parking is expensive

review_title: it OK to stay here as transition
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Kansas City, MO
pros: The benefit of at university of missouri-kansas city is not so bad. Another good thing is it is pretty convenient due to the location: downtown area.
cons: If you stay at university of missouri-kansas city for a long time, it will be not good for your career development opportunities. It is OK to stay here as transition.

review_title: The work environment is very friendly and supportive from my professors to work as a Research Assistant.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Professors are supportive and friendly. I could manage with my course work and the research work. Can go to trips and enjoy my vacations too. Students can learn new things. Takes much care  for employees .
cons: Need to do most of the things on our own.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Kansas City, MO
pros: Latitude to choose course content and material.
cons: It is an angry, politically charged workplace. You must watch your back at every turn because every imaginable obstruction will present itself. There is no management. The students rate the professors and turnover is incredible.

review_title: Find a good department and you will love it here
job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Kansas City, MO
pros: Amazing co-workers and supervisors; up-to-date software and hardware to effectively complete job tasks; beautiful campus
cons: Relatively expensive parking given the amount of spots available.  The office environment, while great, could benefit from some extra windows.  Days can be long, especially is you have a decen commute.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Kansas City, MO
pros: Access to library. A great coordinator that's trying to make changes for adjuncts.
cons: No benefits, no job security, no interaction with full-time faculty, no office for office hours, no chance for advancement, no access to facilities such as gym, no representation, low pay.

review_title: A great environment with room to grow
job_title: Student Services Coordinator II in Kansas City, MO
pros: Plenty of time off, flexible work schedule, discount tuition for UMKC, centered near great restaurants and shopping, positive impact on the Kansas City community
cons: There is presently a soft freeze, so not every position is guaranteed to be replaced, we have also recently had some bad publicity regarding the Bloch School

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: Gained lots of hands on experience in networking, allowing for knowledge needed in the future. Worked around class schedule.
cons: Are some things they thought you should already know, even  though you may not have been taught them in classes

review_title: Traditional university with traditional hierarchy and processes.
job_title: Career Services in Kansas City, MO
pros: Updated facilities and opportunities to listen to guest speakers and participate in other events.  Diverse student population and friendly (mostly) co-workers.  Healthy PTO offered.
cons: Low paying salaries, even with increased job duties and less staff.  Slow to make or implement changes and tenured co-workers with negative attitudes.

job_title: Student Programmer in Kansas City, MO
pros: As a student, the job helps me in polishing my programming skills and learn new technologies. In this way i still get connected with professional environment. It enhances my skills for academic projects.
cons: The technologies available for work are little bit out dated. They need required upgrades just to synchronize with industry level software development

job_title: Student Lab Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: very good people that treats each other with respect and supports each other. We have kept up with technology trends and this has truly helped my career
cons: We are moving very fast, which is why we are growing and having so much success, but we all work hard for it

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: It has given me an opportunity to work with courses i have learnt. Gave me an opportunity to connect with people.
cons: The subject that I taught was related to my minor so it gave me some experience related to my minor studies but not major which is electrical power systems.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: very family orientated, laid back college atmosphere, in a great area of the city
cons: no team mentality, everyone out for themselves. lots of red tape,  no raises.

job_title: Career Coach in Kansas City, MO
pros:
- Good people - for the most part 
- Small campus - creates an environment where staff, faculty, and students can connect easily
cons:
- Parking is minute 
- Major neglect of professional development and growth opportunities within the company 
- There is a lot of structural and value change happening

job_title: Laboratory Technician in Kansas City, KS
pros: Faculty is very supportive and easy to work with. Training was thorough and I felt very comfortable completing tasks afterward. It was easy to meet and network with other research staff at UMKC. Very flexible with class schedule.
cons: I have no cons for this organization/position

job_title: Honors Discussion Leader in Kansas City, MO
pros: You create your own lesson plans to teach students seeking honors credit. Great support from staff in the honors department.
cons: I didn't feel like I was compensated enough for the amount of quality work that I put in each week for the discussion group.

job_title: Instructor in Kansas City, MO
pros: Connected to the MU system, benefits package, retirement plan
cons: Poor pay when considering workload.  Inequity in pay rates.  Salary increases cause increase in service fees.  Unbalanced approach

review_title: Great people to work with! From the Dean to the students
job_title: Student Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Can work in between classes, and hours are fairly flexible
cons: Hours are very limited, 20 hours for student assistant during the fall and spring semester and up to 26 during the summer

job_title: English Tutor in Kansas City, MO
pros: This job was pretty good for me. It gave me a little extra money that helped me pay for books and small luxeries.
cons: I couldn't continue it after I graduated, because it was only for current students.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros:
Many things learnt in a short duration.
Good experience grading and tutoring Graduate students and exploring technologies.
cons: Very tight deadlines, as there is always something new to be shown in class. Last minute tutorial changes are often.

job_title: Medical Transcriptionist in Iron Mountain, MI
pros:
Able to work independently in your home office.
Can work around your busy schedule.
Very interesting work.
cons:
Requires a rather large investment for home office equipment and software.
Low pay requires long hours
Sitting for hours on end.

review_title: Good place to work in every way except salary
job_title: Lecturer in Kansas City, MO

cons: Salary is not competitive, which may be a problem generally in institutions of higher ed in Missouri

job_title: Student Developer in Kansas City, MO
pros: Healthy environment to achieve a good knowledge.
cons: I haven't found any. There are strict timeline for project development but it will help an individual to get accommodated themselves to work in heavy deadlines.

job_title: in Blue Springs, MO
pros: it really depends on your professor and who is you research superior

review_title: Wonderful company that promotes your personal growth

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Kansas City, MO

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Kansas City, MO

review_title: I enjoyed working for UMKC and wish i could still be employed with the company
